questions.text: Which of the following cestodes requires only one host?
questions.solution:
Hymenolepis nana requires only one host for its development. Man serves as the host for H. nana.

Usually, cestodes complete their life cycle in 2 different hosts except:

  • Hymenolepis requires only 1 host, man.
  • Diphyllobothrium requires 3 hosts

Parasite requiring a single host to complete its development is said to have a direct life cycle.

Parasites having a direct life cycle are:

Protozoa Helminths
  • Entamoeba histolytica
  • Giardia lamblia 
  • Trichomonas vaginalis
  • Balantidium coli 
  • Cryptosporidium parvum 
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis 
  • Isospora belli
  • Microsporidia.
  • Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Enterobius vermicularis 
  • Trichuris trichura 
  • Ancylostoma duodenale 
  • Necator americanus 
  • Hymenolepsis nana.

Related Pearl: Difference between cestodes, trematodes, and nematodes

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal pain for the last 4 days. Stool microscopy is shown below. The eggs present in the stool float in a saturated solution of salt. Which of the following can you use to treat her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the egg seen on stool microscopy are suggestive of infection with Hymenolepis nana.  A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice.

The Hymenolepis nana eggs have a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread-like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float in saturated salt solution and are non-bile stained.

Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children and is usually asymptomatic. In heavy infections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.

The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulosae.

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:

  • Epilepsy
  • Increased intracranial tension
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Transient paresis
  • Behavioral disorders
  • Aphasia
  • Visual disturbances.

The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:

  • Scolex within a cyst
  • Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
  • Nodular calcifications
  • Focal enhancing lesions
  • Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented to the ER with complains of abdominal discomfort, indigestion, nausea and diarrhea after consuming measly pork. Stool examination reveals round eggs as shown in the image below.  Which of the following statements is true regarding the causative organism?

choices.text: Eggs are not infective to man
The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution

questions.solution:
Development of the given symptoms following the consumption of measly pork is suggestive of intestinal taeniasis caused by Taenia solium (pork tapeworm). The eggs of Taenia solium do not float in the saturated salt solution.

The eggs of T. solium are infective to man and pigs. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only to cattle and not to man.

The adult worm of Taenia solium is usually 2-3 meters long and the scolex has dagger-shaped hooks.

Man is the definitive host. The intermediate host is usually pig, but occasionally it can be man.

The below image shows the life cycle of T. solium.

questions.text: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The adult form of echinococcus is seen in dogs and other canids which are its definitive hosts.

The larval stage is passed in intermediate hosts such as sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel, and man.

Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to the intimate handling of dogs or by eating raw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces.

Note: Humans can become accidental definitive hosts, second intermediate hosts, or paratenic hosts for spirometra. These are cestodes belonging to the Diphyllobothriidae family. They cause a condition called sparagnosis.

The image below shows the life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver?
questions.solution:
Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver.

E. multilocularis leads to formation of a multilocular hydatid cyst, most commonly affecting the liver. It presents as multiple small cysts in the liver.

Note: Echinococcus granulosus causes a hollow fluid-filled unilocular cyst in the liver.

The CT below shows water lily sign, which is seen in the hydatid disease of the lung. It is caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

The water-lily sign occurs due to detachment of the endocyst membrane from the cyst wall giving the apparance of floating membranes within the pericyst. This mimics the appearance of a water lily.

It is classically visualised on plain radiographs (mainly chest X-ray) when the collapsed membranes are calcified but may be seen on ultrasound, CT, or MRI.

questions.text: While examining a patient with right upper quadrant pain, you note the abdomen is soft with localised tenderness present. CT abdomen findings are given below. Based on these findings, you post the patient for a PAIR procedure. Which of the following is not used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and CT findings are suggestive of hydatid disease of the liver. Hypotonic saline is not used as a scolicidal agent for the PAIR procedure (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, and Re-aspiration) which is the treatment of choice in the early stages of this condition.

Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa.

In PAIR the steps involved are:

  • USG or CT guided puncture of the cyst
  • Aspiration of the cyst fluid
  • Injection of scolicidal agent
  • Re-aspiration of fluid after 5 minutes

The following agents can be used as scolicidal agents:

 Scolicidal agent

Complications associated with it

Cetrimide

Acidosis

95% Alcohol

Cholangitis

Hypertonic saline

Hypernatremia

Sodium hypochlorite

Hypernatremia

Hydrogen peroxide

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a history of progressive breathlessness and cough for 3 months. A chest X-ray was done which showed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the right lung. Wedge resection of the lesion was done and the histopathology image is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological slide showing the hydatid cyst are suggestive of infection with Echinococcus granulosus.

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

  • Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
  • Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
  • Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

The clinical features of hydatid disease of lung are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis and chest pain. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole.

The below image shows the histology of hydatid cyst.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms does the given life cycle belong to?
questions.solution:
This is the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum. It is also known as fish tapeworm or broad tapeworm.

The 3 hosts of Diphyllobothrium latum are:

  • Definitive host- man, dog, and cat.
  • First intermediate host- freshwater crustacean 
  • Second intermediate host- freshwater fish.

The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called oncosphere.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented to you with complaints of tingling and numbness in her legs. On examination, her hands appear as shown in the image, ankle reflex was absent and Romberg's test was positive. Which of the following is most likely implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with cutaneous hyperpigmentation and features of subacute combined degeneration are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. This can be caused by Diphyllobothrium latum.

The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of vitamin B12 and interferes with its ileal absorption leading to vitamin B12 deficiency. This can also lead to megaloblastic anemia (Bothriocephalus anemia).

In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurological features of vitamin B12 deficiency like:

  • Tingling and numbness
  • Bilateral lower limb weakness
  • Bilateral hypertonia
  • Sensory ataxia (Romberg's positive)
  • Absent deep tendon reflexes.

It is treated with parenteral vitamin B12 supplementation.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms most commonly causes Katayama fever?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Katayama fever is most commonly caused by Schistosoma mansoni.

It is an immune complex mediated disease caused by antibodies to the schistosomulae, adult worms, and eggs. This acute illness consists of fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and allergic manifestations.

The diagnosis is by the demonstration of the eggs in feces.

Praziquantel is effective in the treatment. Glucocorticoids are given to suppress hypersensitivity reactions.

Instances of Katayama fever are rarer in infections with Schistosoma haematobium compared to S. mansoni.

*Note: Katayama fever is most commonly caused by S. japonicum and S. mansoni. But, among the given options, S. mansoni is the most common cause of Katayama fever.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, intermittent abdominal pain, and burning micturition. He gives a history of swimming in a freshwater lake 10 days back. Urine microscopy shows the following. Which of the following is the causative agent?

choices.text: Schistosoma species cannot be determined based on egg

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and image showing an egg that is non-operculated with the terminal spine at one pole are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma hematobium.

Species differentiation of schistosoma can be done based on the location of the spine as follows:

  • Terminal spine- Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine- Schistosoma mansoni
  • Rudimentary lateral spine- Schistosoma japonicum

The image below shows egg of Schistosoma mansoni. Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein.

Adult worms of S. japonicum live in the superior mesenteric vein draining the ileocecal region. They are also seen in the intrahepatic portal venules and hemorrhoidal plexus of veins.

The image below shows an egg of Schistosoma japonicum.

 Adult worms of S. hematobium live in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins.

questions.text: A 50-year-old fisherman presented with complaints of blood in the urine. A diagnostic cystoscopy was done and the microscopic view of the biopsied specimen is given below. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma of the urinary bladder. It is associated with Schistosoma hematobium infection. 

Chronic schistosomiasis presents as painless hematuria, dysuria, and proteinuria. Fibrosis may cause obstructive uropathies like hydronephrosis and hydroureter. It has been associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Such malignancy is detected in a younger age group as compared to transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.

The following parasites cause malignancies:

  • Schistosoma hematobium- bladder carcinoma
  • Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini- bile duct carcinoma

questions.text: Identify the parasite from the given life cycle.
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Fasciola hepatica.

Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals.

Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.

The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation. Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.

Most infections are asymptomatic. Halzoun is a painful pharyngitis caused by the presence of adult flukes on the posterior pharyngeal wall after eating raw sheep liver. Obstructive jaundice can occur months or years later.

Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms does the given life cycle belong to?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Clonorchis sinensis. It causes clonorchiasis (Asian liver fluke infection).

The hosts for Clonorchis sinensis are:

  • Definitive host- humans
  • First intermediate host- snail 
  • Second intermediate host- fish

Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae (metacercariae). In the duodenum, metacercaria will undergo excystation and migrate to bile ducts to develop into adult worms. The eggs containing miracidia are excreted in human feces which are then ingested by snails. Miracidium hatches out in the midgut of the snail. Inside the snail, sporocyst develops into 1st and 2nd generation redia and then to cercariae. The cercariae now penetrate the fish and develop into metacercaria (infective form).

Chronic clonorchiasis is strongly associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: A wet mount examination of the stool sample of a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea is given below.  Which of the following parasites is he likely infected with?
questions.solution:
The given image showing an operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) in the stool sample is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica infection.

The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained. They contain an immature larva (miracidium) and do not float in the saturated salt solution.

The following are the parasites with operculated eggs:

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Fasciola gigantica
  • Paragonimus westermani
  • Opisthorchis felineus
  • Clonorchis sinensis
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis
  • Diphyllobothrium latum

Eggs of Schistosoma japonicum, Enterobius vermicularis, and Ancylostoma duodenale are non-operculated. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient has a history of travel to China and the consumption of pickled crab. He now complains of rusty sputum and cough. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani.

Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human gut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled with golden-brown eggs.

Praziquantel (25 mg/ kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.
